text:
<https://www.uncorkedstudios.com/blog/Uncorked-Studios%27-Summer-Internship-Program-Turns-Six-this-Year/|The Uncorked Studios' Summer Internship Program Turns Six this Year!>
Our interns have had their hands in all sorts of projects here at the studio—many of which display our culture of curiosity and knack for prototyping. From creating an <http://www.uncorkedstudios.com/work/interactive-sandbox/|interactive sandbox> that playfully changes color in response to each user’s gestures to <https://vimeo.com/140840763|building robotic arms that respond to facial expressions>, our interns have run the gamut on experimentation.

But an...

attachments.title: The Uncorked Studios' Summer Internship Program Turns Six this Year!
attachments.text: Our interns have had their hands in all sorts of projects here at the studio—many of which display our culture of curiosity and knack for prototyping. From creating an interactive sandbox that playfully changes color in response to each user’s gestures to building robotic arms that respond to facial expressions, our interns have run the gamut on experimentation.But an internship at Uncorked involves more than just internal or self-driven projects, as some of our interns have also had the chance to contribute to our larger endeavors, such as helping to build Sommely (an intelligent IoT wine tracking system) or participating in the development of our latest installation for Google’s BrandLab team.
attachments.fallback: The Uncorked Studios' Summer Internship Program Turns Six this Year!

attachments.title: Digital Meets Physical
attachments.text: From scrappy startups to major technology brands, some of the most innovative work we do at Uncorked is helping our clients imagine the future through concept product design and development. While these projects provide an exciting mix of creative and technological challenge, the reality of working on these future-facing products means we don’t often get to talk about them outside the walls of Uncorked. From the very beginning of the project we made a conscious decision to use the browser as our canvas.

text: The beginning looks great, <@U06DFL7BP>! Do you know what the other links are that are popping up after? Is it also basically showing all the links in the post in the RSS?
Is it possible to just have it show the link to the post and opening paragraph?
I think that's slack expanding the links
Ah. Is there a way for it not do that?
Don't feel like you need to get back to me right away. Just curious.
As we think about future sharing.
I don't think so unless we strip from the message
I'll look at it. This is default behavior
Just thought it looked kind of odd b/c there were so many links.
